This means that you can message people nearby even if thereâ€™s no cell signal or internet connection

This person is proposing that we look at the conflict in Gaza as a prelude to the future of how war *ought* to be prosecuted, not a critical take and judgement, or even haunted prognostification of war could and would be, but will and *should*; this is more or less an endorsement of the actions if not an argument that NATO (the paper mostly talk about NATO forces) *should be doing like in Gaza*.

To that end, the paper ends with
> The nature of warfare is changing amid technological advancements and global urbanisation, but the enduring lesson from Gaza remains: those who learn, adapt and prepare will succeed. Western forces should act swiftly to implement the lessons learned, carefully adjust tactics to their specific context and **address any gaps revealed by the Gaza conflict in their current strategies.** By doing so, they will transform todayâ€™s insights into tomorrowâ€™s preparedness, ensuring that **when Western soldiers are ordered to fight in a city again,** they are ready to win quickly, decisively and in accordance **with the values they uphold."**
This is worse than the drowned horses.

That the second section (2.1) of the report is entitled "Civilian Protection and the Legitimacy Dilema" would be offensive, but the second paragraph of it reads:

> From the outset of its Gaza campaign, the IDF took measures to warn civilians and urge them to evacuate combat zones. It dropped flyers, sent mass text messages and made phone calls urging residents to move south or leave specific neighbourhoods.  These practices likely saved thousands of lives by prompting numerous civilians to flee (hundreds of thousands did evacuate northern Gaza early in the war). 

We know that such outreach was often not done with adequate forewarning and that warnings/agreements have demonstrably **not** stifled the killing of over 70k Palestinians.

In the weird and wild world of oddity collecting, in the US is it legal to sell ethically sourced human remains.  That is until well, they aren't ethically sourced. The difference between a legal and ethical niche hobby and criminal possession  is CONSENT.  This week one "bone seller" was charged after being caught grave robbing a PA historic cemetary. 

Like many online sellers of human bones, his Facebook page shows photos of him holding skulls and that he was active in human bones selling groups. On his instagram, titled â€œLedger of the Deadâ€ it reads, â€œProvenance & forensic documentation of human & animal remainsâ€ and describes him as a â€œcurator of specimens, pathology & osteologyâ€, implying he was an ethical trader.  A recent post there shows a skull with a roughly quarter-sized hole thatâ€™s missing a part of its jaw mounted on a pole against a dark background with white flowers.  The post includes the text, â€œIf you know, you know. skulls/bones available. dm to inquire. from my personal gallery.â€  

Gerlach has now been charged with nearly 500 counts of theft, receiving stolen property, abuse of a corpse, criminal mischief, burglary,  desecration of monuments and desecration of burial places.

Hey there, happy new year, and nice of you to want to help. (skip to the end for the advice part)
I'm sure you've already gotten a reply from the mods. While I don't know their answer, I'll take a wild guess here... But I still want to give you a community-oriented response: This isn't the kind of research we usually assist with. While Bellingcat is an 'open-source-first' outlet/community, we usually try to keep the focus really on issues that are journalistic in nature. There are other (OSINT) communities that will be more receptive to requests that relate to finding individuals. I assume your request is genuine, but apart from  <#710991734246473809> and https://www.bellingcat.com/about/editorial-standards-practices/ it's just not 'our thing' if you know what I mean.

There are other communities that focus on this kind of work, and while I don't know whether or not they will allow you to post the information you have (my guess is that it's unlikely), they will probably be more experienced with things like data minimization, opsec, etc. (Prefer those that have a formal intake and handoff process.) You could try TraceLabs.org, locate.international, or osint.uk, maybe KASE, doenetwork.org, websleuths.com, or the gratefuldoe subreddit. 

That being said, my advice would be to 
a) as a good general rule - never post screenshots/photos from a phone that's not yours. 
b) Hand the phone in **where it was first found**. This is where the owner will check first. Lost and found, local police, municipal lost-property service. (Also, that's required by law in most jurisdictions anyway.)
c) Keep it charged so that Apple's intended recovery channel has a chance to work.

Good luck!

Apologies - this will be long.  Overall, I would say there's three core strategies for checking if, in your case, a chatbot is sharing falsehoods:
1. Direct Interrogation
2. Indirect Corroboration
3. Inference from existing data

__Direct Interrogation__: As long as the chatbot session is still active you should be able to interrogate it about *how* it knows the things it's telling you. Ask for citations and require that it confirms them. If the chatbot cannot provide valid sources, push it to explain where it discovered this information. You're basically pushing the chatbot to be honest with you about where it's getting this information. If it can't/won't tell you where it's from, it's probably safe to assume it's fabricated. 

__Indirect Corroboration__: If you still want more evidence, take what you can validate to a non-AI source of information. For example if the chatbot gave you a legal name of someone who lives in a specific city; can you find evidence that there's someone with that name in that city? If it tells you that a crime took place; is there a police report or news story with evidence about that crime? If, on the other hand, the chatbot isn't giving you any kinds of anchoring facts, you should be skeptical of anything it's implying as a fact. 

__Inference__: Even with the information you have right now you should be able to judge the likelihood that it's telling you facts. You say that it's about an FBI case - how would a chatbot know about that? Does it seem like it's found something novel that no human has yet uncovered? How likely do you think that a chatbot has an original idea? Chatbots are notorious for telling users something *that the user wants to hear*. Is that happening now? You could, what what you've heard already, make a decision it's making this up. Then, regardless of the objective truth, you can assume it's a falsehood.

The political implications are very difficult to gauge at the moment. There is a great degree of public outrage (https://discord.com/channels/709752884257882135/709946606144847872/1449709209515069522), but with a very close election coming in April, everyone in the government and government media is scrambling to manage public opinion and either try to sweep this under the rug, or control the narrative through anything ranging from new appointments to lead child care institutions to astounding degrees of victim blaming.
There hasn't been comprehensive polling data published since the two major reports came out, so I don't really know more than that. Plus I mostly exist in Budapest, which is a bit of a progressive/liberal bubble, so the attitude here is likely not entirely representative of how the country as a whole is reacting to the issue.

As for the 90% of cases pursued having been dismissed, it's not clear to me how many of these were dismissed maliciously, or due to a lack of specialised personnel who could support the investigation. I think it was even mentioned in one of the above reports that many of the victims had to wait 9+ months after reporting abuse for a specialised psychologist to talk to them, at which point authorities usually claimed that the incidents happened too long ago to reasonably investigate.

Yes, it's an appropriate question for this thread. Although part of it would fit in data-science as well. Your question essentially has two parts, right?
First, you want to know about the tools to get the data, and maybe visualize it. 

I use Apify and Octoparse for X analysis. They're not free, but pretty cheap for what they offer. They use the advanced search function. Apify in particular is worth the money (although Octoparse delivered somewhat better results for some reason in my testing - about 30% more tweets returned in some specific cases). 
You can make requests from your home computer automatically using python and JSON.  

You can also use free solutions using puppeteer and selenium, or if you prefer something more manual, I would point you in the direction of https://bellingcat.gitbook.io/toolkit/more/all-tools/zeeschuimer

For visualization, you could go any number of routes, depending on your question. Gephi is infamous, Maltego is very manual but I love it, and then you could go any number of ways to  visualize more complicated graph data models...

Thank you to the mods for allowing me to post this â¤ï¸ 
(I have marked all images with numbers, so that is what I am referencing below.)
The Challenge: I wanted to test the model's ability to handle "void" environments, specifically generic desert highways with zero signage or distinct landmarks (see Image 1).

The AI Lead: Instead of hallucinating a random desert in Nevada or UAE, the model correctly identified the specific "semi-arid" vegetation and road infrastructure style of Central Kazakhstan.

Prediction: Kyzylorda Region, Kazakhstan (70% Confidence) (see Image 2).

Result: It placed the pin on the correct highway (M32/E38).

Verification & Accuracy: The estimate was ~133km off from the actual coordinates, but crucially, it placed me on the correct road corridor (see Image 3).

Verdict: It didn't give the exact mile marker, but it successfully narrowed down a continent-sized search area to a single highway stretch. For a "zero metadata" image, I consider this a solid starting point for manual verification.

Location used for the challenge: https://maps.app.goo.gl/4GUhbjLD8278ArYq5
My model predicted: Unknown, Kazakhstan, 45.0000Â°, 65.0000Â° with a 25 km error radius. (Note: I know the coordinates seem weirdly perfect, but I promise this is a coincidence. Try the model yourself to see how it normally guesses.)

Try the tool (Free/No Login): https://www.geolocator.app/demo (Feedback on my version 3's accuracy is welcome)

I should probably clarify. When setting up accounts that you want to look unique and authentic, the key is to make each computer/session look as unique as possible. If you head down to the Starbucks and rapid fire create three Google accounts from the same browser session - Google knows you did that. The browser cookies can betray that you did that. The tracking cookies for each account will be effectively identical. In short, you'll look inauthentic. 

But if you take the time to create unique virtual machines with their own memory sizes and screen dimensions and OS install parameters... stuff starts to look unique when the services do a browser fingerprint on you. The end goal is to look authentic and unique, realizing that the account creation services are going to do their darnedest to make sure you are.

You're welcome. On the technical side, it uses a model based on CLIP, which gives it general knowledge of things and what they look like, and its ability to "understand" text and images, and then it's fine-tuned on aerial imagery plus OpenStreetMap data, so it learns about infrastructure and things that people put on maps and what they look like from above.

I've been working on a geospatial/aerial imagery semantic search tool for a while. The idea started in 2010 but it was only recently that the tech has become available to implement it in a useful way. It offers a way to do a wide variety of, even ad hoc semantic queries over large datasets very quickly. You want to look for cars? Enter "cars". Cars near water? Just type that in. Similarly for mines, roads, solar panels, police cars, aircraft boneyards. Red buildings with "Iran Air Cargo" painted on the roof? type it in. It's multi-modal, so you can also query with images. Have an aerial image of an S-200 site and you want to find more? Upload it. That last one is actually in the demo video, which shows off some of the capabilities: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EjH0kMEz4YY

It's not better than a custom model for identifying any particular thing, but it does a good job of identifying a huge variety of things, and it's very fast.

ðŸ‘Š We've just shared a short investigation into a far-right fight night that happened in California at the end of August.
Far-right fight nights are events bringing together combat fighting, extremist bands and merch, in an attempt to bring in new recruits and solidify existing relationships. Researcher <@975351092986658846> locates the latest event for a California-based far-right group: https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2025/09/15/active-club-fight-night-2025-san-diego/?utm_source=discord 
Although the organising groups publicise their operations to their followers, owners of the venues used for these events are often unaware of what is happening behind closed doors or who the organisers really are. Sadly, in this case, an event owner was duped and told it was a booking to film a commercial for an activewear brand. 

If you want to look further into these networks and how they operate, check out <#813082873862160384>

How do you monitor a conflict in a region that is difficult to access and rife with misinformation claims? In this comprehensive guide, we take you through the processes required to identify and verify what is really happening in a conflict, using the recent violent uprisings in Manipur, India as an example. Nothing is permanent on social media. Users deleting their posts or webpages can lead to the erasure of a trail of evidence that may be crucial to your investigations. But how do you keep that vital data? We've improved our Auto Archiver tool to make archiving your sources easier and set it up to be more manageable to navigate as a research team... https://www.bellingcat.com/resources/2025/08/13/the-open-source-tool-that-has-preserved-150000-pieces-of-online-evidence/?utm_source=discord 

Launched publicly in 2022, our Auto Archiver tool has helped newsrooms and NGOâ€™s preserve over 150,000 web pages and social media posts to date. It is a staple in our newsroom. 
If you work in a newsroom or research team and want to access a demo or help to deploy the Auto Archiver internally you can reach us at contact-tech@bellingcat.com with the Subject â€œAuto Archiver at [my team/organisation]â€ and tell us more about your organisation and archiving needs.

Of course no tool is perfect and weâ€™re looking for feedback, if you have suggestions for the tool please reach out via an issue in our GitHub: https://github.com/bellingcat/auto-archiver

As someone who has been doxxed and much worse, I chose to have several versions of myself online. 

A- the one that I don't hide who I am, for work that requires transparency and B- everything else: research accounts, sock puppets, whatever you want to call them where there's a risk to safety for someone.

I value safety over transparency when having to make a decision between the two, and I assess this often.

A new report by Bellingcatâ€™s Justice & Accountability (J&A) Unit and the Global Legal Action Network (GLAN - Global Legal Action Network) detailing the use of cluster munitions in civilian areas in Kharkiv at the beginning of the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine is published today. The report is based on 32 in-depth investigations of separate incidents that took place between February and April 2022. It offers one of the most detailed looks yet at the use of cluster munitions against civilian areas, a practice that raises serious questions regarding violations of International Humanitarian Law.  https://j-and-a.glanlaw.org/kharkiv

Bellingcatâ€™s J&A Unit helped build mechanisms for open source research to enhance legal accountability processes, particularly in cases of atrocity crimes. This report signifies the last piece of research that will be conducted by Bellingcat as part of this team.

GLAN is continuing its OSI accountability work, and you can find out more about that and any legacy J&A projects here: https://j-and-a.glanlaw.org/

Working with our partners Evident and CalMatters we have monitored the LA raids, discovering recurring trends and tactics used by officers. 
We collected videos of more than 100 incidents of arrest between June 6 and June 30 in Los Angeles and the immediate surrounding areas. The footage shows agents from the likes of Border Patrol (BP) and, Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arresting people in public spaces, from car washes to swap meets, with officers often obscuring their identities and sometimes using significant force.  https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2025/07/08/masked-armed-and-forceful-finding-patterns-in-los-angeles-immigration-raids/?utm_source=discord

Landmines and other unexploded ordnance litter a large part of Ukraine today, including along once fertile and important agricultural land. We all know AI models can now create realistic images and videos but how do they fare at identifying where a real image was taken? Bellingcat researchers have put large language models to the test; we ran 500 geolocation tests, with 20 models each analysing the same set of 25 images. The images varied in difficulty to geolocate and none of them had been published online before. Find out which LLM performed best and which one failed at identifying our geolocation challenges more than others here: https://www.bellingcat.com/resources/how-tos/2025/06/06/have-llms-finally-mastered-geolocation/?utm_source=discord

A wealthy sportsman and oil tycoon was shot on the driveway of his Corpus Christi, Texas home by two gunmen in waiting. Despite witnesses, no one was convicted for the murder.

A January operation in the central Californian city of Bakersfield saw dozens detained by US border patrol agents operating more than 300 miles from the US southern border. Agents from the El Centro division of US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) claimed the mission was highly targeted and aimed to apprehend immigrants with criminal records. Yet exactly how targeted it was has become a point of significant tension. With partners Evident and Calmatters we explore this claim and geolocate 50 videos showcasing where CBP units were operating during the operation.
https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2025/04/08/us-border-patrol-called-raid-300-miles-from-border-targeted-open-source-evidence-suggests-otherwise/?utm_source=discord

Gathering aerial footage of Gaza is a dangerous task. Bellingcat and our partners at Forbidden Stories/ARIJ/Paper Trail Media/Die Zeit/ Der Standard/ Le Monde/RFI identified several cases where drone journalists were killed or injured shortly after capturing aerial images. On Thursday, the fantastic people behind the Open Source Munitions Portal (OSMP) will be joining us for a Stage Talk. The free-to-use tool aims to provide a key resource to democratise information about conflict and open up access to understanding munitions use.
They offer nearly 1000 reference images of a variety of munitions from active conflict zones, each reviewed and assessed by at least two munitions experts. Key information is provided about each image, including reported location, tentative model of munition and, where relevant, analyst notes written by experts at ARES. They've also got guides to key munition types, explainer videos, and a simple glossary of key terms on there. Recently the team launched the first of a series of articles using 3D interactive models to explain how to identify some of the most widely used munitions - including linking these models to relevant images from the archive. In the talk we'll be discussing all of these features and taking your questions on identification of munitions, so come with some prepped! Find us in the Stage area on Thursday at 12pm EDT/5pm CET.
https://discord.gg/3u4SVNuP?event=1348681170598105179

Once you're an expert in the OSMP, we'll be back speaking on munition identification in two weeks time, when we'll be joined by previous Bellingcat tech fellow Andro Mathewson for our next Stage Talk. Amongst the inauguration news yesterday we forgot to share our research here! 
If you haven't seen it yet, here's our latest:
Adverts selling Nitazenes, an opioid up to 500 times stronger than heroin, are all over the internet, from social media platforms to trade sites. Even trace quantities of this drug can cause an overdose with the opioid already causing hundreds of deaths in Europe, the UK and North America. With our Estonian partner Postimees we investigated more than 1,000 online adverts selling six of the most common types of nitazenes to the public and explored how this deadly drug is infiltrating Europe and beyondâ€¦ https://www.bellingcat.com/news/2025/01/20/chinese-link-to-nitazenes-targeting-europe/?utm_source=discord

Welcome to a new week,  the week of Trump back in the White House! 

Due to his ability to take over the news, we're today announcing the https://discord.com/channels/709752884257882135/1330709161385922650 for all of your Trump discussion <:badboy:1144554466603966535> . 
On the day that Trump discussed acquiring Greenland, Bluesky and X feeds (among others) were taken over by the news, drowning out other areas of interest. We donâ€™t want the same thing to happen in this server, where to find relevant open-source information, users have to scroll through endless articles about Trump. 
Secondly, many things that Trump says donâ€™t go farther than him saying them and the resulting media response, critique, and public outrage. We want to contain that talk and response to the Trump Containment Zone, but emphasise that actual actions he or his administration takes should be discussed in the normal channels: 

With those points in mind, the #TrumpContainmentZone should be used as follows: <:turmp:1050085050517049394> 
News about a statement from Trump
News where the entity that Trump is talking about (in the above example, Greenland) responds
Any sort of analysis of the resulting back and forth (eg, â€œHow much would it cost for the US to purchase Greenlandâ€, â€œHow would the US go about invading Greenlandâ€)

The following information (still using the above example), would be allowed to leave the Trump Containment Zone:

Yeah something on this too, while researching criminal organizations themselves (outside actual cyber groups) may come with "lesser" physical risks, there's absolutely still issues of their own to focus on that could go sideways. It's why with actual OPSEC you assess based upon operational specifics, not just a broad "do this".
One thing I do and advise heavily when covering that angle, if you are ever having to deal with pictures and social profiles, do not ever use photos of people with their children, that is how you can cross a red line that probably wouldn't be thought of. There's nearly always other pics to use also, so, it is kinda just good practice not to use those. Do not post about their homes or vehicle license plates either, you might think that's fine - that could get them and their family killed while out to eat breakfast on Sunday (their respective adversaries look at all this stuff if they can to harm them too, just, physically instead of article exposes).

Idea - FEMA related disinformation and Hurricane Milton and Helene. Disinformation during weather events has always been a thing (I can tell you more about the rumors of levee bombing during Katrina), but in particular, the massive push this time of FEMA disinformation as a US election issue.
Points, as I have my coffee:
- FEMA is a federal agency and current disinformation pushers dream of dismantling as many federal agencies as possible
- Low information in US areas that aren't normally impacted by hurricanes: people may say "FEMA is only giving x" while not understanding that state level programs, personal insurance, local services, etc, are filling in other gaps. It is indeed a patchwork 
- Lack of working tech infrastructure can lead to the fallback of old telephone-style networks, where word passes around by mouth

Welcome to the Bellingcat Discord! On behalf of the team, we appreciate you joining. 

**Below are some tips and pointers to help guide you through the server:**

1.  Always keep in mind that **this is an open server.** That means that absolutely anyone can join, including bad actors. That means that there are bad actors in this server, watching. So, never share anything on here that you wouldn't want the entire world to know about, including bad people. 

2. Bellingcat does not endorse any project or initiative by any member(s) of this server unless otherwise explicitly stated by Bellingcat. 

3. Whether youâ€™re an open source research professional or just getting started, thereâ€™s a place for you on this server. We encourage you to ask questions and get involved in conversations. Donâ€™t be shy! Here is a Google Doc with some introductory resources: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1MuV_NeZ0FiQNJbPkx7jwMgntjGcRKFF1MoCZhJ7G_-Y/edit?usp=sharing

4. If you're new to the server, we recommend that you lurk for a few days to get a feel for the place. That way, when you're ready to post, you'll fit right in!

5. Some channels (like the one dedicated to the invasion of Ukraine) may contain graphic content. In order to view these channels, you must first visit <#1023777114262093855> and click the â€œI agree to view sensitive mediaâ€, if you so choose. 

6. If youâ€™d like, you can introduce yourself to your fellow server members in the <#966599459754618930> channel. Feel free to share anything youâ€™d like about yourself, like what your research interests are or what open source skills youâ€™d like to develop.

7. If you have any questions, comments or concerns about the server, please send a message to <@575252669443211264>. 

8. If your Discord nickname is inappropriate for the tone and vibe of our community (for example, if it references graphic sexual acts/organs/fluids), or if it contains invalid characters, you will get a new nickname free of charge courtesy of the Wu-Tang Clan Name Generator! If your profile contains inappropriate content, you'll be kicked from the server and invited to re-join after you've edited your server profile accordingly.

9. We have an agreement with the other big open source servers (Project Owl, Kase, OSINTION, and Trace Labs) to crossban across our servers. That means that if you're banned in our server, you may also be banned in those other servers and vice versa.

10. The opinions expressed here by Bellingcat staff are their own and don't necessarily represent Bellingcat's official opinions.

The purpose of these rules is not only to adhere to Discord's Community Guidelines, but also to help foster a community where you can feel welcomed to learn from others and make meaningful contributions. We want your experience in this server to be an example of the principles and values that we at Bellingcat hold, including collaboration, tenacity, diversity, ingenuity, and integrity. 

The server rules are:

**1. Treat everyone with respect.** Absolutely no harassment, witch hunting, sexism, racism, or hate speech will be tolerated.
     A. This includes our Server Moderators. The moderating team is made up   of dedicated volunteers who want you  to have a good experience here. Please treat them with respect. 

**2. Sharing links or images that contain graphic content for its own sake is strictly not allowed.** There must be an academic, journalistic, and/or research-related reason for sharing this type of content. When sharing news articles, tweets, or other news media that may contain violence or graphic content, you must spoiler tag it (/spoiler), and you must describe the nature of the content to avoid people from clicking on it accidentally. 
    A. Do not post content that shows gore or uncensored dead bodies. 
    B. If you must share a graphic image for geolocation, use an image editor (like MS Paint) to remove the graphic content.
    C. If you're not sure about any of the above, DM a <@575252669443211264> .

**3. Do not post anything that violates Discord's Community Guidelines.** As a Discord user you should be familiar with the Community Guidelines, which can be found here: https://discord.com/guidelines

**4. This is not a server for debating politics/religions/economics/etc.** As a Bellingcat community hub, the purpose of this server is to learn about open source research, and share and analyze news. If you want to debate your opinions, please keep it in DMs. 
A. Occasionally, the moderating team will ask server members to refrain from engaging with certain emerging topics. This will usually be the case with topics that require a high level of technical, scholarly or insider knowledge that the server lacks. Whenever we make a request to refrain from engaging with a topic, we will post an explanation in â <#924344679812726797>.

**5. No spam or self-promotion (server invites, advertisements, etc.) without permission from a staff member or server moderator.** This includes DMing fellow members. When in doubt, please DM a staff member. We'll almost always say "yes!" to your request.
A. Sharing crowdsourcing campaigns for money is not allowed in this server.
B. Advertising paid services or products is not allowed in this server. 
C. Please don't advertise your services. If you're looking for work, check for postings in <#709760136222212127>.

**6. Absolutely no doxxing (sharing people's personal information) of any kind.**
A. Please do not ask anyone in this server to help you find a person's home address, phone number, email addresses, social media profiles, or anything to that effect. This is  an open server, and we have no way of knowing what your intentions are. 
B. If you are a journalist working on a project and you need help doing this, feel message <@&1212114000020643860> to get moderator permission to post your request. 
C. Don't accuse random people of being bots/malfeasance. 

7. **Articles which contain a description of sexual violence can only be shared in https://discord.com/channels/709752884257882135/1118448280435687506.** Articles that simply mention that sexual violence has occurred as part of a broader conflict may be placed in appropriate regional or other channels.
